abstract: When Procter & Gamble bought Gillette for $57 billion, it picked up a lot more than just razors: The deal gave it Duracell batteries and Braun, whose products include coffeemakers and blenders. Less than two years later, Wall Street is wondering whether it may be time for P&G, a giant of the consumer products business, to tidy up a bit.
lead_paragraph: When Procter & Gamble bought Gillette for $57 billion, it picked up a lot more than just razors: The deal gave it Duracell batteries and Braun, whose products include coffeemakers and blenders. Less than two years later, Wall Street is wondering whether it may be time for P&G, a giant of the consumer products business, to tidy up a bit.
